contentrichtext.text: {{infobox UK place | country = England | latitude = 52.6171 | longitude = 1.4702 | os_grid_reference = TG350077 | official_name = Strumpshaw | population = 602 | area_total_km2 = 11.69 | static_image = | static_image_caption = | shire_district = [[Broadland]] | shire_county = [[Norfolk]] | region = East of England | civil_parish = Strumpshaw | constituency_westminster = | postcode_district = NR13 | postcode_area = NR | post_town = NORWICH | dial_code = | london_distance = |static_image = [[File:St Peter, Strumpshaw, Norfolk - geograph.org.uk - 1247274.jpg|240px]] |static_image_caption= <small>St Peter, Strumpshaw</small> }} '''Strumpshaw''' is a [[village]] and [[civil parishes in England|civil parish]] in the [[English county]] of [[Norfolk]]. It is located on the northern bank of the [[River Yare]] around {{convert|6|mi|km}} south-east of [[Norwich]] within [[The Broads National Park]]. The parish covers an area of {{convert|11.69|km2|abbr=on}} and had a population of 602 in 245 households as of the [[United Kingdom Census 2001|2001 census]].<ref>[http://www.norfolk.gov.uk/consumption/groups/public/documents/general_resources/ncc017867.xls Census population and household counts for unparished urban areas and all parishes]. Office for National Statistics & Norfolk County Council (2001). Retrieved 20 June 2009.</ref> For the purposes of local government, it falls within the [[Non-metropolitan district|district]] of [[Broadland]]. The village lies a little distance from the river, on the slopes of Strumpshaw Hill, the highest area of land in the [[Norfolk Broads]]. Because of its elevation, Strumpshaw hosted, from the late 1790s through to the mid-1810s, a repeater station in the [[Semaphore line#London - Great Yarmouth|shutter telegraph chain]] linking the Admiralty in London with Great Yarmouth. The [[Wherry Lines]] railway line running between Norwich and [[Great Yarmouth]] and [[Lowestoft]] runs through the parish. Trains call at [[Buckenham railway station]] at weekends only. The small villages of [[Buckenham]] and [[Hassingham]], formally both parishes in their own right, lie within the civil parish of Strumpshaw. ==Strumpshaw Hall== Strumpshaw Hall lies closer to the river, next to the railway line. It is the home of the [[Strumpshaw Hall Steam Museum]], with a collection of [[Traction engine]]s, and [[Steam roller]]s. It also has a [[Showman's engine]], a [[Steam wagon]] and a [[narrow gauge railway]] with a [[Simplex]] diesel disguised as a steam engine. ==Natural environment== The [[Strumpshaw Fen RSPB reserve]] is operated by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds. It caters for up to 20000 visitors annually. It is bordered to the east by [[Buckenham Marshes RSPB reserve]] and lies within the [[Mid-Yare NNR|Mid-Yare National Nature Reserve]] and [[Yare Broads and Marshes]] [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]]. == Notes == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category inline|Strumpshaw}} {{Civil Parishes of Broadland}} [[Category:Broadland]] [[Category:Villages in Norfolk]] [[Category:Civil parishes in Norfolk]]
